challenges.title: Analytics Platform Overview
description: //i.imgur.com/s4osQ5T.png
An image of a Jupyter Notebook

You have begun your journey, congratulations. Much of the work that we are going to be doing will utilize Jupyter notebooks. Jupyter notebooks are a flexible computing enviroment that was originally based on iPython notebooks. The Jupyter team has done an amazing job bringing the notebook computing enviroment to a wide variety of languages including R, Python, Scala, and even SAS.

Click on the link below to go to https://try.jupyter.org and browse some of the cool things that you can do with Jupyter Notebooks. We will be using Jupyter notebooks almost exclusively as a way of learning data science. They also provide a great way to collaborate and document your processes using markdown.
https://try.jupyter.org
//i.imgur.com/s4osQ5T.png
An image of a Jupyter Notebook

You have begun your journey, congratulations. Much of the work that we are going to be doing will utilize Jupyter notebooks. Jupyter notebooks are a flexible computing enviroment that was originally based on iPython notebooks. The Jupyter team has done an amazing job bringing the notebook computing enviroment to a wide variety of languages including R, Python, Scala, and even SAS.

Click on the link below to go to https://try.jupyter.org and browse some of the cool things that you can do with Jupyter Notebooks. We will be using Jupyter notebooks almost exclusively as a way of learning data science. They also provide a great way to collaborate and document your processes using markdown.
https://try.jupyter.org
//i.imgur.com/OI5Sp08.jpg
A picture of docker and Analytics Dojo

Unlike a lot of learn to code sites that use in-browser tutorials, the AnalyticsDojo uses the same the same tools you are likely to use in a production environment. This means that before we can get started, we have to go through a bit of setup of an analytics platform.

An analytics platform is an environment in which you can execute programs, store data, and even create web services or Application Programming Interfaces (APIs) that enable your application to be deployed into the world or even sold on a marketplace.

We are going to start with an overview of two different platforms: (1) Docker, (2) Microsoft Azure. Each of them will have their own strengths and weaknesses.

A key to the platforms we are looking at is that they can work with R and Python within a Jupyter Notebook. While we don't currently incorporate Domino, they have a great blog entry on what a data science platform is all about.
https://blog.dominodatalab.com/what-is-a-data-science-platform/
//i.imgur.com/P70wNmS.jpg
An image of the Docker Logo.

When learning analytics, a similar computing environment can ensure that associated examples and exercises will work across a population of users-who may be using a wide variety of different types of operating systems. There are some great ways of being able to run R and Python directly on your laptop. Of course you could install R and the iPython notebook directly. For R, R-Studio is great and for Python Anaconda similarly can get you started. However, often code may function slightly differently on different operating systems and it could be that an example won't work exactly as planned. To get around this, Docker bundles software in a Container that can be rolled out onto different operating systems and even into production. If you don't have a great Internet or will be working a lot offline, you might start with Docker. Otherwise, you might start with one of the preconfigured environments. Feel free to either install Docker now by clicking on the link and following the instructions for your operating system or you can start with one of the cloud environments.
https://docs.docker.com/engine/installation/
//i.imgur.com/6mVM2jC.gif
Gif of the Microsoft Signup Process

Microsoft has developed an incredible platform for data science that works very well with Jupyter Notebooks. If you are just getting started, we suggest that you start here. They also have become a big supporter and player in R-community with their purchase of Revolution Analytics. In addition, their free services are quite generous for individuals learning data science. If you don't already have a Microsoft account, you will have to create one first here. Then follow the link to the AzureML signup page.
https://studio.azureml.net
//i.imgur.com/nfw3AAt.png
A diagram showing the CRISP Model for data mining

But whatever the tools you use, it is most important to understand when and why to apply them. While the 'how' can a challenge the when and why will take more time and we hope that by viewing a wide range of technologies and case studies these will become second nature. To frame the processes of addressing a data science problem, we will be using the Cross Industry Standard Process for Data Mining (CRISP) model to provide a guide. This breaks down analytics into manageable steps. For each, we may utilize different tools and technologies. But before we can get started with data science, let's start with some of the technologies we will be using for data science.
By Kenneth Jensen (Own work) [CC BY-SA 3.0], via Wikimedia Commons
https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File%3ACRISP-DM_Process_Diagram.png
//i.imgur.com/BxNG6Am.jpg
A picture of various analytics platforms

So you've got an account on some really powerful analytics platforms as well as on Github. We have also added resources for each of the platforms on the top right of the screen under Resourcs. Next we can exploer some of the cool things you can do with them.

challenges.title: Docker
description: Before you begin:
Make sure you have installed Docker
and have downloaded the materials' repository
Introduction to Docker
You can always access a command line within the <i>materials</> repository by right clicking on the repository
from within the Github Desktop application.
To launch a docker container on port 8888 enter the command to launch your notebook.

<i>docker run -d -p 8888:8888  -e GRANT_SUDO=yes  --name analyticsdojo  -v {enter path to materials directory}/materials/analyticsdojo:/home/jovyan/work jupyter/datascience-notebook start-notebook.sh <i>
tests: Docker containers run only in the cloud.
Docker containers can't share files with the operating system.

challenges.title: Microsoft Azure
description: Before you begin:
Make sure you can log into https://studio.azureml.net
and have downloaded the materials' repository
Introduction to Azure shows how to upload data and notebooks
Login at https://studio.azureml.net to following along.
tests: Azure datasets are entered directly into notebooks.
You can only access one dataset per notebook.
